{{lang|pt|União dos Parlamentos Africanos}} | nativename_a = | nativename_r = | seal = | seal_width = | seal_caption = | logo = African Parliamentary Union logo.gif | logo_width = 150px | logo_caption = | picture = | picture_width = | picture_caption = | formed ={{Start date|1976|02|13}} | preceding1 = | preceding2 = | dissolved = | superseding = | agency_type = | jurisdiction = | headquarters = 30 Boulevard Roume, Plateau district, Abidjan, Côte d'Ivoire. | coordinates = | motto = For the promotion of democracy and stable development | employees = | budget = | chief1_name =[[Nzi Koffi]] | chief1_position = Secretary General | chief2_name=[[Rachid Talbi el-Alami]] (Morocco) | chief2_position = Chairperson of the Executive Committee | website ={{URL|http://www.africanpu.org/}} | map = | map_width = | map_caption = | footnotes = | embed = }} The '''African Parliamentary Union''', formerly the Union of African Parliaments, is a continental [[Inter-parliamentary institution|interparliamentary organization]] first established in [[Abidjan]] on 13 February 1976. The Union aims to bring together the parliamentary institutions of all the nations of [[Africa]], to encourage contacts among African and world [[Member of Parliament|parliamentarians]], and to strengthen and promote [[democracy]] and peace. Forty parliaments are members of the APU.{{cite web|url=http://africanpu.org/index_english.html|title=African Parliamentary Union (APU)|work=africanpu.org}} The APU holds annual conferences in order to further its goals and also organizes parliamentary meetings in cooperation with International Organizations or Institutions. The working languages of the Union are [[English language|English]], [[Arabic]], [[French language|French]] and [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]. == References == {{Reflist}} {{poli-org-stub}} {{Africa-org-stub}} [[Category:Organizations based in Abidjan]] [[Category:Parliamentary assemblies]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox non-profit |name = Alaskans Together for Equality |image = File:Alaskans Together for Equality logo.png |caption = The Alaskans Together for Equality logo |map = Map of USA AK.svg |msize = 225px |mcaption = [[United States|U.S.]] State of [[Alaska]] |area_served=[[Alaska]] |mission = |motto = |type = |tax_id = |revenue = |location = [[Anchorage, Alaska]] |founded_date = [[2007 in LGBT rights|{{Start date|2007|01}}]] |key_people = |num_employees = |homepage = {{URL|http://www.alaskanstogether.org}} |formerly = Alaskans Together }} '''Alaskans Together for Equality''' is a statewide education and political advocacy organization in [[Alaska]] that advocates for [[lesbian]], [[gay]], [[bisexual]], and [[transgender]] ([[LGBT]]) rights, including [[same-sex marriage]].<ref name="lgbtqn415">{{Cite news | title = Alaska LGBT rights groups ask governor to end appeal of same‑sex marriage ruling | agency = Associated Press | work = LGBTQ Nation | date = April 18, 2015 | accessdate = June 19, 2015 |url=http://www.lgbtqnation.com/2015/04/alaska-lgbt-rights-groups-ask-governor-to-end-appeal-of-same-sex-marriage-ruling/ }}</ref>
== History == Alaskans Together for Equality began in January 2007 as Alaskans Together, a ballot measure committee organized to oppose an advisory vote intended to deny public employees access to same-sex partner benefits. Following the vote, the organization adopted its current structure.<ref name="atfe-history">{{Cite web | title = History | work = Alaskans Together For Equality | accessdate = June 19, 2015 |url=http://www.alaskanstogether.org/history }}</ref>
== Structure == Alaskans Together for Equality is a [[501(c)(4)]] nonprofit organization which lobbies at the local, state, and federal levels of government on LGBT issues.<ref name="lgbtqn415" /><ref name="atfe-history" /><ref name="atfe-home">{{Cite web | title = Alaskans Together For Equality | work = Alaskans Together For Equality | accessdate = June 19, 2015 |url=http://www.alaskanstogether.org/ }}</ref>
Alaskans Together Foundation, Inc. is a [[501(c)(3)]] nonprofit organization which educates the public on LGBT issues.<ref name="atfe-home" />
== Activities == Alaskans Together for Equality endorses candidates for political office and engages in lobbying on LGBT rights.<ref name="lgbtqn415" /><ref name="atfe-home" /><ref name="ap415">{{Cite web | title = Alaskan Together for Equality Endorses Berkowitz | author = Camden Yehle and Drew Phoenix | work = Anchorage Press | date = April 23, 2015 | accessdate = June 19, 2015 |url=http://www.anchoragepress.com/opinion/alaskan-together-equality-endorses-berkowitz }}</ref><ref name="ktuu315">{{Cite web | title = Mayoral candidates scuffle for endorsements | author = Baird, Austin | work = KTUU-TV | date = March 27, 2015 | accessdate = June 19, 2015 |url=http://ak-pipeline.com/?p=7321 }}</ref>
Alaskans Together Foundation, Inc. coordinates public awareness campaigns on LGBT issues.<ref name="atfe-home" />
The organization is a member of the [[Equality Federation]].<ref name="atfe-home" /><ref name="eqfed-members">{{cite web |url=http://equalityfederation.org/members | title=Member Organizations | work=Equality Federation | accessdate=June 19, 2015}}</ref>

The '''Ambassador of Conscience Award''' is [[Amnesty International]]'s most prestigious [[human rights]] award. It celebrates individuals and groups who have furthered the cause of human rights by showing exceptional courage standing up to injustice and who have used their talents to inspire others. It also aims to create debate, encourage public action and raise awareness of inspirational stories and human rights issues.
==Recipients<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/art-for-amnesty/ambassador-of-conscience/|title=Ambassador of Conscience Award|last=|first=|date=|website=www.amnesty.org|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180422194522/https://www.amnesty.org/en/art-for-amnesty/ambassador-of-conscience/|archive-date=April 22, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-22}}</ref>== * 2018 - [[Colin Kaepernick]], former [[NFL]] quarterback and activist; [[kneeling protest]] at racial injustice<ref>{{cite web|language=en|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/21/sports/colin-kaepernick-amnesty-international.html|website=[[NY Times]]||title= Accepting Rights Award, Colin Kaepernick Decries ‘Lawful Lynching’|date=2018-04-21|access-date=2018-04-21}}.</ref> * 2017 - [[Alicia Keys]], American musician and activist; the movement for rights for [[Indigenous peoples in Canada|indigenous people]] in [[Canada]]<ref>{{cite web|language=fr|url=https://www.amnesty.fr/presse/prix-ambassadeur-de-la-conscience-2017-alicia-keys|website=amnesty.fr|title=Prix Ambassadeur de la conscience 2017. Alicia Keys et le mouvement des droits des autochtones du Canada, lauréats de la prestigieuse récompense d'Amnesty International|date=2017-04-13|access-date=2017-06-29}}.</ref> * 2016 - [[Angélique Kidjo]], Beninese singer-songwriter and [[Lutte Pour Le Changement]] (LUCHA), a youth movement committed to peaceful protest in Goma and [[Le Balai Citoyen]], a political grassroots movement in Burkina Faso and [[Y'en a Marre]], a group of Senegalese rappers and journalists * 2015 - [[Joan Baez]], American folk singer, songwriter and activist and [[Ai Weiwei]], Chinese contemporary artist and activist * 2013 - [[Malala Yousafzai]], Pupil, blogger, activist and [[Harry Belafonte]], American singer, human right and social justice activist * 2009 - [[Aung San Suu Kyi]], leader of the Burmese [[National League for Democracy]]. The award was subsequently withdrawn on Nov. 12, 2018. * 2008 - [[Peter Gabriel]], musician and humanitarian activist * 2006 - [[Nelson Mandela]], former [[President of South Africa]] * 2005 - Irish rock band [[U2]] and their manager [[Paul McGuinness]] * 2004 - [[Mary Robinson]], former [[President of Ireland]] and [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights|UN High Commissioner for Human Rights]], and [[Hilda Morales Trujillo]], [[Guatemala]]n [[women's rights]] activist * 2003 - [[Václav Havel]], former [[List of presidents of the Czech Republic|President of the Czech Republic]]

[[Christian Institute]] |leader_title = Convenor |leader_name = [[Philip Giddings]] |founder = |membership = |membership_year = |website = {{url|anglicanmainstream.org}} }} '''Anglican Mainstream''' is a conservative [[Anglican]] organization from the [[Church of England]]. It describes itself as "a community within the [[Anglican Communion]] committed to promote, teach and maintain the Scriptural truths on which the Anglican Church was founded".{{cn|date=July 2012}} It is best known through its website, which posts items of interest or concern to its constituency. The convenor of the organization's UK steering committee is [[Philip Giddings]].[http://www.anglican-mainstream.net/anglican-mainstream-who-we-are/ Anglican Mainstream: Who we are] ==Britain and Ireland== It brings together Anglicans in the British Isles who are concerned to maintain a traditional position on controversial issues. Participating organisations include evangelical groups in England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland, such as [[Reform (Anglican)|Reform]], [[Church Society]], the Church of England Evangelical Council, the New Wine network, the Scottish Anglican Network and mission agencies. It has close links with similar groups in North America and South Africa. ==Anglican realignment== Anglican Mainstream is also involved in partnering with growing churches in the developing world through Anglican International Development (AID).{{cite web|url=http://interanglicanaid.org/ |title=International Anglican Aid |publisher=Interanglicanaid.org |date= |accessdate=2012-07-09}} It has strong links with the [[Fellowship of Confessing Anglicans]],{{cite web|url=http://www.fca.net/ |title=Fellowship of Confessing Anglicans |publisher=Fca.net |date=2008-06-29 |accessdate=2012-07-09}} and supports the [[Anglican realignment]] and the [[Global Anglican Future Conference]] (GAFCON).{{cite web|url=http://gafcon.org/ |title=Global Anglican Future |publisher=GAFCON |date= |accessdate=2012-07-09}} ==Social conservatism== {{Main|Homosexuality and Anglicanism}} Anglican Mainstream is concerned about a number of social issues including abortion and end of life issues, the status of marriage and family, evangelism, the cultural challenge of secular society and general Anglican church life in Britain and overseas. Of all the issues with which it is concerned, its stance on issues of sexuality has drawn controversy, particularly its support for sexual abstinence for homosexual people and the [[ex-gay movement]], which it considers to be a minority group often ignored or silenced. Liberal pro-homosexuality groups such as Changing Attitude have been particularly opposed to Anglican Mainstream, especially over their view that homosexual orientation is an unalterable fact of human nature.{{cite web|author=January 30th, 2012 |url=http://changingattitude.org.uk/archives/5057 |title=The shocking failure of Anglican Mainstream’s cure for homosexual ‘lepers’ |publisher=Changing Attitude |date=2012-01-30 |accessdate=2012-07-09}}"The Royal College of Psychiatrists believes strongly in evidence based treatment. There is no sound scientific evidence that sexual orientation can be changed. Furthermore, so-called treatments of homosexuality create a setting in which prejudice and discrimination flourish." http://www.rcpsych.ac.uk/pdf/rcpsychposstatementsexorientation.pdf In 2012, Anglican Mainstream was part of a coalition of Christian groups intending to run a two-week campaign in which some [[London]] buses would carry an advertisement reading “Not gay! Post-gay, ex-gay and proud. Get over it!” in the same style as adverts produced by [[Stonewall (charity)|Stonewall]], the gay rights group. The intention was to draw attention to the existence of ex-gays and the possibility of change, a claim which is contradicted by some mainstream psychologists).{{cite web|url=http://www.anglican-mainstream.net/2012/04/12/london-bus-campaign-challenges-stonewalls-claim-that-gay-is-innate/ |title=Blog Archive » London bus campaign challenges Stonewall’s claim that “gay” is innate |publisher=Anglican Mainstream |date=2012-04-12 |accessdate=2012-07-09}} After receiving appropriate permissions the campaign was then prohibited by London's mayor, [[Boris Johnson]], because of the offence he believed it would cause.{{cite web|author=Pippa Crerar, City Hall Editor |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/mayor/boris-johnson-why-i-banned-gay-cure-bus-ads-7660738.html?origin=internalSearch |title=Boris Johnson: 'Why I banned gay cure bus ads' - Mayor - News - Evening Standard |publisher=Thisislondon.co.uk |date=2012-04-19 |accessdate=2012-07-09}}{{cite web|url=http://www.anglican-mainstream.net/2012/04/19/anglican-mainstream-accuses-london-mayor-of-censorship/ |title=Blog Archive » Anglican Mainstream accuses London Mayor of Censorship |publisher=Anglican Mainstream |date=2012-04-19 |accessdate=2012-07-09}} ==See also== * [[Reform (Anglican)]] * [[Core Issues Trust]] * [[Mediawatch-UK]] ==References== {{reflist|3}} ==External links== *{{official website}} [[Category:Anglican organizations established in the 21st century]] [[Category:Anglican realignment]] [[Category:Christian political organizations]] [[Category:Church of England]] [[Category:Evangelicalism in the Church of England]] [[Category:Conservatism in the United Kingdom]]

[[File:Bondi brennandi hus.jpg|thumb|250px|A peasant begs a mercenary for mercy in front of his burning farm during the [[Thirty Years' War]]. Contemporary illustration.]] The [[Latin language|Latin]] phrase '''bellum se ipsum alet''' ({{lang-en|The war will feed itself}}) or '''bellum se ipsum alit'''Cooper (1979), p.402 ({{lang-en|The war feeds itself}}, {{lang-fr|La guerre doit se nourrir elle-même}}),Cadiou (2008), pp.579–580 and its [[German language|German]] rendering ''Der Krieg ernährt den Krieg''Kudla (2001), p.221 describe the [[military strategy]] of feeding and funding armies primarily with the resources of occupied territories. The phrase, coined by [[Ancient Rome|Ancient Roman]] statesman [[Cato the Elder]], is primarily associated with the [[Thirty Years' War]] (1618–1648). ==The phrase== [[File:Marco Porcio Caton Major.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Cato the Elder|Cato]], coined the phrase in 195 BC]] The phrase ''bellum se ipsum alit'' was first mentioned in ''[[Ab Urbe Condita (book)|Ab urbe condita libri]]'' XXXIV,9,12, written by [[Roman Empire|Roman historian]] [[Livy|Titus Livius (Livy)]] (59 BC-17 AD), who attributed it to [[Cato the Elder|Cato Marcus Porcius ("the Elder", 234–149 BC)]], a statesman in [[Ancient Rome]].Lauterbach (2002), p.101Demandt (1978), p.60 According to Livy, Cato in 195 BC used the phrase during the [[Roman_Conquest_of_Hispania#The_wars_of_conquest|conquest of Hispania]] when he refused to buy additional supplies for his army in [[Iberian peninsula|Iberia]] ([[Hispania]], modern [[Spain]] and [[Portugal]]). The slogan became prominent in reference to the [[Thirty Years' War]]. [[Friedrich Schiller]] in his retrospect, semi-historical drama [[Wallenstein (play)|Wallenstein]] (I/2, ''The [[Piccolomini]]''), has [[Johann Ludwig Hektor von Isolani]], a general in [[Albrecht von Wallenstein]]'s army, say these words in a conversation with other commanders:Schiller (1798) in Alt (2004), p.319
{| |-valign="top" bgcolor="#fafffa" |Illo: |''Ei was! Es war ein gutes Jahr, der Bauer kann / Schon wieder geben!'' |''So what! It was a good year, the peasant is able to give again!'' |-valign="top" bgcolor="#fafffa" |Questenberg: |''Ja, wenn Sie von Herden / Und Weideplätzen reden, Herr Feldmarschall -'' |''Yes, if you are talking about herds and pasture grounds, field marshal Sir! -'' |-valign="top" bgcolor="#fafffa" |Isolani: |''Der Krieg ernährt den Krieg. Gehn Bauern drauf / Ei, so gewinnt der Kaiser mehr Soldaten.'' |''The war nourishes the war. Peasants die, ah! This way the Emperor gains more soldiers.'' |-valign="top" bgcolor="#fafffa" |Questenberg: |''Und wird um so viel Untertanen ärmer!'' |''And loses so many of his subjects!'' |-valign="top" bgcolor="#fafffa" |Isolani: |''Pah! Seine Untertanen sind wir alle!'' |''Pah! We all are his subjects!'' |}
==The strategy== ===Thirty Years' War=== {{further|Raubwirtschaft}} Prior to the [[Thirty Years' War]], the laws of the [[Holy Roman Empire]] provided for funding armies by raising special war taxes.Krüger (2005), p.37 The funds needed for the large armies raised during the war however exceeded the income of the respective warlords from those taxes, and forced them to resort to additional, unfavourable measures such as borrowing of money and currency depreciation. In the course of the war, the principle of ''bellum se ipsum alet'' was applied in two phases: First, the food supplies needed for the army were derived directly from the territory occupied by this army. Later, the pay for the soldiers was derived from the occupied territory as well. [[File:Johann Tserclaes Tilly.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Johann Tserclaes, Count of Tilly|Tilly]], the first to implement ''bellum se ipsum alet'' on occupied enemy territory in 1623]] In 1623, the principle was implemented by the [[Upper Saxon Circle]] on its own territory, and by [[Johann Tserclaes, Count of Tilly]], commander of the [[Catholic League (German)|Catholic League]]'s army, on occupied enemy territory. The Upper Saxon Circle had raised an army for its defense, and dispersed it over its territory. The territory was divided into ''Kontributionsbezirke'' ("contribution districts"), each of which had to provide certain amounts of food for the soldiers as well as the horses. The soldiers were quartered in the houses of ordinary people, who had to provide shelter, food and ''Servisgeld'', a defined sum to allow the soldier to buy firewood and salt. These measures were self-imposed by the circle's nobility, and the local authorities were given the task of their implementation. In contrast, Tilly imposed analogous measures in the same year on a territory he had just conquered, [[Hersfeld]]. The contributions he demanded were unreasonably high, and were collected with military means. In 1625, [[Albrecht von Wallenstein]] had promised [[Holy Roman Emperor]] [[Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor|Ferdinand II]] to raise an army and fund it himself.Beier (1997), p.151 Ferdinand II allowed Wallenstein to exploit occupied territoryFerdinand II: "[...] in den eroberten Orten und Landschaften zur Erhaltung der Soldatesca leidliche Contributiones und Anlagen zu machen." Krüger (1995), pp.37–38. with the caveat that money should not be collected by force without his approval.Krüger (2005), p.38 This caveat was however neglected, and the army was fed and paid entirely by contributions and war loot. Subsequently, all armies participating in the war adapted the ''bellum se ipsum alet'' principle. Contributions from occupied territories, divided into ''Kontributionsbezirke'', were collected by military force and by local authorities forced to cooperate. The affected territories were thereby ruined. The need to borrow money to satisfy the military demands during the Thirty Years' War resulted in an indebtedness that many German communities bore until the 18th century. ===World War II=== [[File:Goeringcaptivity2.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Hermann Göring|Göring]] applied ''bellum se ipsum alet'' on occupied Soviet territory in 1942]] During [[World War II]] [[Nazi Germany]] [[Operation Barbarossa|invaded the Soviet Union]] in 1941. The conquered territories did not return as many resources as the Nazis had expected, due to previous shortfalls of the Soviet [[planned economy]] and the devastations during the conquest.Neumärker (2007), p.144 Thus, ''Reichsmarschall'' [[Hermann Göring]] implemented restrictions on the local population to prevent the [[Altreich (pre-1938 Nazi Germany)|Altreich]] and the army from falling short of food supplies. Aware of the consequences of these measures, Göring in September 1941 foretold "the largest starvation since the Thirty Years' War" in the occupied areas.Göring: "[...] das größte Sterben seit dem Dreißigjährigen Krieg." Neumärker (2007), p.144. In 1942, he explicitly described the Nazi strategy in these territories as ''bellum se ipsum alet''.Göring: "Der Krieg ernährt den Krieg. Das wird jetzt ganz groß geschrieben." Neumärker (2007), p.144. ==See also== *[[Scorched earth]], a strategy designed to counter ''bellum se ipsum alet'' ==Notes== ==Sources== ===References=== {{reflist|2}} ===Bibliography=== {{refbegin}} *{{cite book|title=Die Chronik der Deutschen|first=Brigitte|last=Beier|publisher=wissenmedia|year=2007|isbn=3-577-14374-6|language= German}} *{{cite book|title=Hibera in terra miles: les armées romaines et la conquête de l'Hispanie sous la République, 218-45 av. Denken|first=Alexander|last=Demandt|publisher=Beck|year=1978|isbn=3-406-04696-7|language=German}} *{{cite book|title=Formung der frühen Moderne|chapter=Kriegsfinanzen und Reichsrecht|first=Kersten|last=Krüger|publisher=LIT Verlag|location=Berlin-Hamburg-Münster|year=2005|isbn=3-8258-8873-8|url=https://www.google.com/books?id=OdtChJ6XHTUC&pg=PA37|accessdate=2009-09-09|language=German}} *{{cite book|title=Lexikon der lateinischen Zitate|editor-first=Hubertus|editor-last=Kudla|edition=2|publisher=C.H.Beck|year=2001|isbn=3-406-47580-9|language=German}} *{{cite book|title=Latein – Deutsch: Zitaten-Lexikon|first=Ernst|last=Lautenbach|publisher=LIT Verlag|location=Berlin-Hamburg-Münster|year=2002|isbn=3-8258-5652-6|url=https://www.google.com/books?id=qepmsXSNHtsC&pg=PA101|accessdate=2009-09-09|language=German}} *{{cite book|title=Görings Revier: Jagd und Politik in der Rominter Heide|first1=Uwe|last1=Neumärker|first2=Volker|last2=Knopf|publisher=Ch. {{Infobox award | name = Pura Belpré Award | image = | imagesize = 250px | caption = | description = excellent portrayal of Latino experience in children's literature | presenter = [[Association for Library Service to Children]], a division of the American Library Association | country = United States | year = 1996 | website = {{URL|ala.org/alsc/belpre}} }}
The '''Pura Belpré Award''' is a recognition presented to a Latino or Latina writer and illustrator whose work best portrays the Latino cultural experience in a work of literature for children or youth. It was established in 1996.<ref name=home/> It was given every other year since 1996 until 2009 when it was changed to be given annually.<ref name=about/>
The award is named in honor of [[Pura Belpré]], the first Latina librarian from the New York Public Library. As a children's librarian, storyteller, and author, she enriched the lives of [[Latino]] children through her pioneering work of preserving and disseminating Puerto Rican folklore.<ref name="about" />
The award is given by the [[Association for Library Service to Children]] (ALSC), a division of the [[American Library Association]] (ALA), and the National Association to Promote Library and Information Services to Latinos and the Spanish-Speaking ([[REFORMA]]).<ref name=about/>
==Criteria==
* Two medals shall be awarded at the annual conference of the [[American Library Association]], one to a Latino author and one to a Latino illustrator, for creating outstanding original children's (age 0-14) books that portray, affirm, and celebrate the Latino cultural experience. * For purposed of this award, Latino is defined as people whose heritage emanates from any of the Spanish-speaking cultures of the Western Hemisphere. * The award-winning books must be published in the United States or Puerto Rico. * The committee is not to consider the entire body of work by an author or whether the author has previously won the award. * Recipients of the Pura Belpré Medal must be residents or citizens of the United States or Puerto Rico. * Fiction and nonfiction books for children published in Spanish, English, or bilingual format are eligible. * Honor books may be named. * If suitable candidates are not found, the awards will not be presented in that year. * One person may be selected to receive the awards in both categories.<ref name=terms/>

==Recipients of Multiple Medals and Honors== [[George Ancona]], [[Yuyi Morales]], and [[Duncan Tonatiuh]] have received medals or honors for their roles as both author and illustrator. Duncan Tonatiuh is the only person to receive multiple awards in one year for two different works.
===Belpré Medals=== <!-- PLEASE RESPECT ALPHABETICAL ORDER WITHIN EACH SECTION --> One person has won five Belpré Medals. * [[Yuyi Morales]], as illustrator 2004, 2008, 2009, 2014, 2015.
One person has won three Belpré Medals. * [[Margarita Engle]], as author 2008, 2009, 2016.
Multiple people have won two Belpré Medals: [[Julia Alvarez]] as author, Susan Guevara as illustrator, Rafael López as illustrator, and [[Pam Muñoz Ryan]] as author. <!-- Medal dates JA 2004, 2010 SG 1996, 2002 RL 2010, 2016 PMR 2002, 2011 -->
===Belpré Honors=== <!-- PLEASE RESPECT ALPHABETICAL ORDER WITHIN EACH SECTION --> One person has won seven Belpré Honors. * [[Duncan Tonatiuh]], as illustrator 2011, 2014, 2015, 2016, and twice in 2017; as author 2014.
One author has won four Belpré Honors *[[David Díaz (illustrator)|David Diaz]], as illustrator 2004, 2006, 2010, 2011.
Multiple people have won three Belpré Honors. * [[Francisco X. Alarcón]], as author 1998, 2000, 2002. * [[George Ancona]], as illustrator 1996, 2000; as author 2011. * Carmen T. Bernier-Grand, as author 2006, 2008, 2010. * [[Lulu Delacre]], as illustrator 1996, 2006, 2009. * [[Margarita Engle]], as author 2011, 2012, 2014. * [[Rafael López (illustrator and artist)|Rafael López]], as illustrator 2006, 2012, 2014. * [[Yuyi Morales]], as illustrator 2004, 2010; as author 2009. * John Parra, as illustrator 2010, 2015, 2018.
Multiple people have won two Belpré Honors: Amy Córdova as illustrator, Angela Dominguez as illustrator, Carmen Lomas Garza as illustrator, and Juan Felipe Herrera, and [[Francisco Jiménez (writer)|Francisco Jiménez]] as author. <!-- Honor dates AC 2009, 2011 AD 2014, 2016 CLG 1996, 1998 FJ 2002, 2009 JFH 2000, 2015 --> ===Medal and Honor=== <!-- PLEASE RESPECT ALPHABETICAL ORDER --> Several authors have received both a Belpré Medal and a Belpré Honor: Raúl Colón, [[David Díaz (illustrator)|David Diaz]], [[Margarita Engle]], Carmen Lomas Garza, Susan Guevara, [[Rafael López (illustrator and artist)|Rafael López]], [[Meg Medina]], [[Yuyi Morales]], [[Pam Muñoz Ryan]], and [[Duncan Tonatiuh]].
====Works with Multiple Awards==== <!-- PLEASE RESPECT CHRONOLOGICAL ORDER --> * ''Diego: Bigger than Life'' was the subject of two honors for author and illustrator in 2010. * ''The Storyteller's Candle'' was the subject of two honors for author and illustrator in 2009. * ''Just In Case'' was the subject of a medal for illustrator and an honor for author in 2009. * ''Los Gatos Black on Halloween'' was the subject of a medal for illustrator and an honor for author in 2008 * ''Doña Flor: A Tall Tale About a Giant Woman with a Great Big Heart'' was the subject of a medal for illustrator and an honor for author in 2006. * ''César: ¡Sí, Se Puede! Yes, We Can!'' was the subject of two honors for author and illustrator in 2006. * '''El Gallo de Bodas: A Traditional Cuban Folktale'' was the subject of two honors for author and illustrator in 1996.

{{primary|date=November 2014}} The '''Center for Global Food Issues''' is a project of the [[Hudson Institute]], a conservative [[United States|U.S.]] [[think tank]]. It describes its aims as to promote agricultural free trade, encourage technical innovation in agriculture, and raise environmental awareness among farmers.<ref name=about>[http://www.cgfi.org/about/ About CGFI]. www.cgfi.org. Retrieved 23 November 2014.</ref>
The Center has received criticism from the [[Union of Concerned Scientists]]<ref>[http://www.ucsusa.org/publications/earthwise/win0405-earthwise-earth-friendly-farm-friendly.html Dialogue] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071204203348/http://www.ucsusa.org/publications/earthwise/win0405-earthwise-earth-friendly-farm-friendly.html |date=December 4, 2007 }}. ''[[Earthwise]]''. Volume 7 Number 1. Retrieved 12 November 2007.</ref> and other [[organizations]].{{Fact|date=June 2007}}
[[Dennis T. Avery|Dennis Avery]] is the Director.<ref name=about /> His son, [[Alex Avery (researcher)|Alex Avery]], is the Director of Research and Education.<ref>[http://www.gmwatch.org/profile1.asp?PrId=14 Alex Avery] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060930125952/http://www.gmwatch.org/profile1.asp?PrId=14# |date=2006-09-30 }}. [[GM Watch]] profile. Retrieved 12 November 2007.</ref>
The Center manages additional websites, including: * BSE News<ref>[http://www.bsenews.com]</ref> * Milk is Milk<ref>[http://www.milkismilk.com]</ref>
